dmca.title: Photographer Demands Payment from Forums Registered Copyright Agent
dmca.body:
-----Original Message-----
From: pixintl@pixintl.com [mailto:pixintl@pixintl.com] 
Sent: Friday, August 18, 2006 10:49 PM
To: owner@mediablvd.com
Cc: legal@pixintl.com
Subject: Copyright infringement-CEASE AND DESIST 3 images
Importance: High

I am the photographer of the images appearing on your website cited below.
I had copyrighted them with the US Copyyright office in December 2005
under my name.You can verify this by going to the us copyright site and
puting in my name,[private]. You will see I have over 80,000 of my
images copyrighted.I have the original certificates on file.Photography is
how I make my living and when losers like your company allow this you hurt
me and my family.This is the second time you've been served notice.Failure
to remove these images in 3 days gives me the right to file suit against
you and the poster for $150,000 per image(x3= $450,000+) in addition to
all legal costs and expenses. I was recently awarded a setllement by the
judge in another infringment case.Filing suit and persuing is not
something I fear and will protect my images and copyright no matter what
the cost.

Remove or I will see you all in court.

I swear under oath that I,[private](pixintl.com) am the photographer
and copyright holder of the images of members of "Prison Break" images as
listed and these images MUST be removed and destroyed. This was image
theft and willful infringement.

page:
http://www.mediablvd.com/forums/index.php?showtopic=[----]

image:
Robin in Chicago

image:
Stacy Keach & Wade Williams:

image:
Rockmond Dunbar and his wife, Ivy at the GRO Magazine Launch:




RESPONSE
-----Original Message-----
From: [private]@mediablvd.com 
Sent: Friday, August 18, 2006 11:00 PM
To: pixintl@pixintl.com
Cc: owner@mediablvd.com; legal@pixintl.com
Subject: Re: Copyright infringement-CEASE AND DESIST 3 images

Dear [private] (pixintl.com):

Your Claim of Web Copyright Infringement has been received, and found to be in
compliance with a proper notification under the DMCA. The links to the images
have been removed from the forums of Web Media Entertainment LLC/MediaBlvd,
and a notification has been sent to the individual responsible for posting the
alleged infringing material that the images have been removed.

A copy of our DMCA statement is appended to this email.

Thank you for contacting us about this matter.

Best Regards,

[private]
Web Media Entertainment, LLC





RESPONSE DEMANDING PAYMENT FROM COPYRIGHT AGENT
-----Original Message-----
From: pixintl [mailto:pixintl@pixintl.com] 
Sent: Sunday, December 31, 2006 3:28 PM
To: [private]@mediablvd.com
Cc: legal@pixintl.com
Subject: Re: Copyright infringement-CEASE AND DESIST 3 images

30 December 2006

You never paid our invoice for the 3 images you stole and posted at a 
large resolution on your site.
If you do not contact us within 14 days to pay us,we will not 
hesitate to file a willful copyright infringement suit against you.
All of our images are registered within weeks of a photo shoot with 
the US copyright office.

We were recently awarded a judgement in our favor from a similar case.

Should we file suit,this will cost you $150,000 per image(x3) and 
all legal costs which could run to $50,000.

Will you be paying our invoice for a license or do we contact our 
international IP attorney and proceed with a lawsuit ?

[private],PixIntl


RESPONSE
-----Original Message-----
From: [private]@mediablvd.com 
Sent: Sunday, December 31, 2006 10:16 PM
To: pixintl
Cc: legal@pixintl.com; owner@mediablvd.com
Subject: Re: Copyright infringement-CEASE AND DESIST 3 images

Dear [private],
I am unaware of an invoice from you. Please re-send if you believe you have a
reason to do so. MediaBlvd is, in part, a hosting service much as Yahoo,
Google, and other sites, but on a smaller scale, in which users are allowed to
post content. The Digital Millenium Copyright Act was created to cover such
instances in which an internet user would post copyrighted material 
without the
knowledge of the host, to prevent the impossible requirement of a hosting
service to validate the content posted by literally millions of users, 
or to be
responsible for copyright infringement for unmonitored postings by 
users of the
service.

I'm fully of the belief that you gave us a proper notice under this act, and
that we complied with our requirements by immediately removing links and
informing the user who originally posted the material in question. MediaBlvd
has no liability to you, in my belief and understanding of the law.

If you or your representatives provide a proper order from the court, 
we will of
course comply to provide proper contact information for the
poster who you believe infringed your copyright.


Best Regards,
[private]
MediaBlvd.com



RESPONSE


-----Original Message-----
From: pixintl [mailto:pixintl@pixintl.com] 
Sent: Friday, January 05, 2007 6:18 PM
To: [private]@mediablvd.com
Cc: legal@pixintl.com
Subject: Re: Copyright infringement-CEASE AND DESIST 3 images

We will be resending the invoice over the weekend. The photos you 
posted are mine.I OWN the copyright. I am the photographer. If you 
did not go out with YOUR camera and cover the event,then you know the 
images do not belong to you.They were exclusive images of mine that 
were stolen and posted full res on your site and made availablel for 
others to take and circulate and for others to profit from.

A judge has recently awarded us in another similar copyright 
infringement.

My photos are registered prior to this infringement talking with the 
US Copyright office which allows us to pursue for $150,.000 per image 
as well as all legal fees.

You make money from your web postings and websites;photography is my 
livelihood for 30 years and why should publications pay for a 
license to publish and you post stolen images ?

The invoice will be forthcoming this weekend. We had contacted you 
more than once to remove the images and your site did not comply.

Regards,

[private],PixIntl.





________________________________________
From: pixintl  
Sent: Monday, January 08, 2007 1:26 AM
To: [private]@mediablvd.com
Cc: legal@pixintl.com
Subject: Re: Copyright infringement-CEASE AND DESIST 3 images invoice atatched

[private],Mediablvd.

Dear Mr. [private]:

Attached is our invoice for images that appeared on MEDIABLVD for more than 5 months.

I am the photographer and copyright holder of these exclusive images that were pirated from one of our agencies we had contributed to at the time. I own all rights and the agency never licensed them to you but as the copyright holder I am the one that has the task of protecting and policing my work.

I have been a professional photographer in the entertainment industry for 30 years. I've spent tens of thousands on my equipment,many years in starvation mode as I honed my craft,studied, and learned the business that I started 30 years ago. This is my company, this is *my* product and how I support myself and my family. I am not a paparazzi. to cover this event,I spent $40 in taxicabs and an hour in travel time. I stayed at a party in a smoky room (I get sick on smoke) and then spent $15 to have my clothes dry cleaned and an hour the following day cleaning my gear and removing sensor dust from the smoky party. After the party I spent 5 hours post processing the images,keywording,captioning and making everyone looked "pretty" and then uploading and staying up till 6am just to make sure the upload made it online.
Our days are 18 hours,7 days a week.But then i chose this profession.Just to throw this in for the record that these images don't create themselves and the photog does not get smashed and parties allnight..
When our work is stolen it just doesn't appear on one site. Almost everyone who sees an image they like,snags it and passes it on and posts it on another site and yet another site.It is "out there" forever.

Eventually it finds its way onto auction sites where fans sell mass quantities of our photos as prints and on unauthorized CDs.

Not only do we lose money from licensing our images to legit publications with credibility and decent licensing fees,but it also puts a professional photographer in a situation of mistrust with PR firms and celebrities when they find out how these images are being used. Especially the ones they gave you exclusive access to cover their event.
Merchandising is a strict no no.

In some cases we have to sign agreements on these issues with PR firms and film studios which also includes the clause,"No yellow journalism.".
So when these images also find their way on sites that love to ridicule the celebrities,again,not nice,makes us look bad too.You can't stop someone from slamming someone,but jus don't use our picture to illustrate hate rage or anger..

When someone steals a rights managed image and throws it into the public domain,they have done the virtual equivalent of breaking into our bank accounts or stealing from our homes.

Our archive of images built up thru the years is very valuable. We take alot of care and pride in our work and we do not sit back watching it get abused.
We do not enjoy lawsuits but if that what it takes to be paid for our work being used,the courts award the copyright holder. And they award us very handsomely when we have registered our
images with the US Copyright office within the set amount of time granted. The images in question were registered Feb 10,2006. Certificate number [private],. you can verify this thru the US Copyright website at: www.copyright.gov or call the office in Washington,DC.

As a a rule we do not license to websites but have in a few instances with a set size,watermark with our name and web and all of our copyright info embedded in the INFO section viewable in Photoshop or similar programs. Copyright info also has to appear next to an image as well. Our rates are based on the viewership of a blog and generally runs $100-300.00 a month per image. We use the Fotoquote program which is now the standard in the industry and also adapted by Photoshelter as well.

Attached is a courtesy invoice for this use and we are not out to take users to the cleaners,but be paid for our licensing our work. Especially when blogs and sites are making revenue from their work.. We ask that all copies of our images be destroyed.

payment can be made by cashiers check or Paypal. We can send you a PAYPAL invoice is you prefer to use that method.

If we do have to go the legal route with you,we just will have file a copyright infringement suit which allows us to collect up to $150,000 per image plus all legal fees since all of our images are registered with the US copyright office.

We've recently been awarded in another case where the judge ruled in our favor.
Should our lawyers in Colorado step in,the bill for all fees goes to the person the site that housed the infringement.the publisher.
I am the legal representative of this company as well as the copyright holder. The average fee for a copyright infringment suit for legal fees is $30-50,000.

Regards,
[private]
pixIntl (Pix International,LLC)

[private]
Chicago,IL.
